p: Melanin is a pigment produced by melanocytes that provides the skin with protection against harmful damage caused by ultraviolet (UV) sunlight, toxic drugs, and chemicals [ 1, 2]. In addition, this pigment gives the skin its characteristic color such that any alteration in skin pigmentation may impact the individualâ€™s appearance, and cause significant emotional and psychological distress, as well as reduced quality of life [ 3]. Thus, the increasing demand for treatments to regulate skin pigmentation is a great clinical challenge for both physicians and scientists.
